Fig 7 Research Paper The role of coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species in the single-atom catalyst Cu/In2O3 for the preparation of acetic acid from methane and carbon dioxide Lingwei Yang Writing – original draft Jing Ding Writing – review & editing Jun Li Software Hui Wan ⁎ Guofeng Guan Methodology ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The co-conversion of CH4 and CO2 has emerged as a challenging issue in C1 chemistry. Converting these gases into a high-value product like acetic acid is an attractive solution. In this study, we employed density-functional theory calculations to design dual-active single-atom catalysts M/In2O3 (M=Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd), which incorporated oxygen vacancies. These catalysts were created by introducing metal M into the surface of In2O3 (111) through doping. Cu/In2O3, Zn/In2O3, Ag/In2O3, and Cd/In2O3 were selected based on the stability of forming single-atom catalysts. Our findings indicated that the formation of the M/In2O3 surface activates the In surface activity and significantly lowers the activation energy for methane dehydrogenation. Among them, the Cu1-O3 species on the Cu/In2O3 surface demonstrates a lower activation energy for methane dehydrogenation and C-C coupling reactions. The "H-O-C-O" hydrogenation of CH3COO* species bonded with the "n"-type structure is more realistic. Microkinetic analysis indicated that the average turnover frequency for the forming of acetic acid on the Cu/In2O3 surface is three orders of magnitude greater than that of methyl formate. This research provides theoretical support for the development of copper single-atom catalysts for the efficient conversion of CO2 and CH4 into acetic acid. Graphical abstract This work compared the formation processes of acetic acid from CH4 and CO2 on four different M/In2O3 (M=Cu, Zn, Ag, Cd) surfaces. We found that Cu/In2O3 exhibited the best catalytic performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords DFT Cu1-O3 In2O3 Acetic acid Methyl formate Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Since the beginning of the 21st century, the energy demand has steadily increased. Although the utilization of new energy sources has partly alleviated the energy shortage in recent years, fossil fuels remain the primary component of the global energy structure [1–3]. The use of fossil fuels has propelled industrialization, but it has also resulted in a significant release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, negatively impacting the environment. Nowadays, the conversion of carbon dioxide has become the hottest topic of interest among researchers [4,5], and methane, which is a greenhouse gas, is also receiving significant attention [6–8]. If carbon dioxide and methane could be converted together [9–11], it would have dual advantages in mitigating the greenhouse effect and providing valuable chemical products. A common pathway for the co-conversion of methane and carbon dioxide is through dry reforming of methane (DRM), which has a well-established experimental framework. The primary focus of research in this area is enhancing catalyst durability against sintering and coking through the selection of suitable carrier materials, preparation processes, and additives [12–14]. In recent years, researchers have also explored the transformation of carbon dioxide and methane directly into acetic acid [15], which not only mitigates the adverse effects of the greenhouse effect but also generates significant economic benefits. Substantial progress has been made both in theoretical and experimental aspects. In addition to the traditional thermal catalytic approach [16–18], non-thermal plasma has emerged as an alternative for studying the conversion process. For instance, Wang et al. [19] discovered that acetic acid exhibited the highest selectivity (40.2 %) among the oxygenated compounds derived from methane and carbon dioxide when non-thermal plasmas were employed. Wang et al. [20] highlighted the influence of copper's valence state on the formation of products: divalent copper favored alcohol production, whereas monovalent copper was crucial for acid formation. On the theoretical side, researchers have gradually shifted from designing catalysts with single active sites to designing catalysts with dual active sites [15]. The construction of dual active sites follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [21], which can largely inhibit the competitive adsorption of methane and carbon dioxide. For example, Shavi et al. [22] first proposed the design of a dual-active catalyst CeO2-ZnO2/MMT, which was subsequently experimentally used with good results, yielding 0.35 mmol of acetic acid. Zhao et al. [23] used DFT calculations and microkinetic analysis to derive that the C-C coupling on the (ZnO)3/In2O3 surface is the dominant step of the reaction. Ban et al. [24] designed the SA-FLP single-atom catalyst TM@CeO2 with dual active centers, utilizing the FLP site for carbon dioxide activation and the SA site for methane activation. This design largely avoided the competitive adsorption of bilayers, resulting in an enhanced selectivity of acetic acid. However, the use of single-atom catalysts [25–27] for methane and carbon dioxide conversion is still in the preliminary stage of exploration. Researchers do not agree on the selection of the central atom that plays a decisive role in methane activation, with common options being Au [28], Nu [29], Zn [30,31], Cu [32], Fe [33], B [34], and others [35,36]. This discrepancy arises from the selection of different substrates, which leads to different coordination environments [37–39] for the loaded or doped metal atoms, consequently affecting the catalytic performance. Therefore, the screening of doped metal atoms on the substrate is critical for the overall reaction. In both experimental [40,41] and theoretical studies [42], indium oxide has emerged as the widely catalyst for methanol synthesis through CO2 hydrogenation. This is primarily attributed to its possession of oxygen vacancies, which facilitate the activation of CO2. Therefore, we have selected indium oxide with oxygen vacancies as our chosen substrate material for this study. Here, we tried to conduct a density functional theory (DFT) study on the preparation of acetic acid from methane and carbon dioxide over single-atom catalysts M/In2O3 (M=Cu, Zn, Ag, and Cd). In addition, the stability of the catalysts will be assessed, and the active sites for methane activation will be identified. Ultimately, we conducted a comparative analysis of the surface formation of acetic acid and methyl formate under realistic conditions, by incorporating microscopic kinetic modeling. Our findings indicated that the Cu/In2O3 catalysts with coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species play a crucial role in methane activation and C-C coupling. The discovery and explanation of the coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species in this study will provide a foundation for the future design of copper-based catalysts. Computational details Using the VASP software package [43], which is based on density functional theory, calculations were conducted for the research. The structural optimization was performed using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the PBE exchange-correlation function [44,45]. The core electrons were described using the projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotential [46]. The interaction between the surface and adsorbate took into account the van der Waals dispersion using the Grimme's DFT-D3 method [47,48]. For the structural optimization, a convergence criterion of 0.03 eV/Å was set for forces. The Brillouin zone was sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grid [49]. The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) and dimer method was employed to search for transition states [50,51]. The transition state was determined by performing frequency analysis on the converged structure, with a force convergence criterion of 0.05 eV/Å, and identifying the unique imaginary frequency. In order to define the thermodynamic stability of a monatomic catalyst, we employ certain calculations to determine its binding energy (Eb) using Eq.(1.1). (1.1) E b = E M / slab − E slab * − 1 n E bulk Here, EM/slab refers to the total energy of the single-atom catalyst, Eslab* denotes the energy of removing one indium atom and one oxygen atom from the substrate, Ebulk signifies the bulk energy of the metal, and n corresponds to the number of metals contained in a metal. The adsorption energy (Eads) is the interaction force between the adsorbate and the substrate, which is calculated as shown in Eq. (1.2). (1.2) E ads = E A / slab − E slab − E A where EA/slab represents the total energy of the adsorbate on the substrate, Eslab refers to the total energy of the substrate, and EA signifies the energy of the free adsorbate. The energy barrier for the reaction (Ea) is defined as shown in Eq. (1.3). (1.3) E a = E TS − E IS where ETS means the total energy of the transition state and EIS means the total energy of the reaction initial state. Lastly, the reaction energy ( Δ E) is defined in Eq. (1.4). (1.4) Δ E = E FS − E IS In this equation, EFS refers to the total energy of the end state of the reaction, and EIS represents the total energy of the initial state of the reaction. Results and discussion Surface models The thermodynamically stable body-centered cubic ferromanganese In2O3 bulk structure with a lattice parameter of a = b = c = 10.18 Å, was utilized for this work [52] Building upon prior research [53], it has been established that the (111) crystal plane is the dominant crystal plane in the structure of In2O3. Notably, In2O3(111) displays an exceptional degree of thermodynamic stability [54,55]. Consequently, we have deliberately chosen In2O3 (111) as the object of our research exploration. This surface is composed of 48 oxygen atoms and 32 indium atoms, arranged in two O-In-O layers. By introducing oxygen defects, the In2O3 (111) surface exhibited exceptional catalytic activity in CO2 conversion [56,57]. As shown in Fig. 1(a), in this study, we removed an oxygen atom from the In2O3 (111) surface to create an oxygen vacancy (OV). Subsequently, the In1 near OV was replaced with a transition metal M (M=Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd) to form a single-atom catalyst M/In2O3. To identify the suitable catalyst for the reaction of CO2 and CH4 to CH3COOH, we calculated the binding energy (Eb) of each metal atom M to assess its stability by using Eq. (1.1) (distribution of Ebulk is illustrated in Fig. S1). We apprehended that the more negative Eb, the higher the stability of M/In2O3. Eventually, we found that the binding energies of Cu (-2.07 eV), Zn (-3.96 eV), Ag (-1.77 eV), and Cd (-3.45 eV) are lower than -1.5 eV [58,59], as shown in Fig. 1(b), which indicates that they are relatively stable. Afterward, This study will examine the reaction mechanism for synthesizing CH3COOH from CH4 and CO2 using the four single-atom catalysts mentioned previously. Interestingly, we have discovered the coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species during the construction of the single-atom catalyst Cu/In2O3. This structure possesses exceptional characteristics and is likely to facilitate the reaction for the synthesis of CH3COOH from CO2 and CH4. Fig. 1(c) shows the coordination environment of Cu, two nearby oxygen atoms and an inner oxygen atom get electrons from Cu atoms, based on the analysis of Bader charge and charge density difference map. Electron localization function (ELF) maps of M/In2O3(M=Cu, Zn, Ag, Cd) were plotted in Fig. S2. Adsorption activation of carbon dioxide and methane For simultaneous adsorption of carbon dioxide and methane, it follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. Methane is adsorbed onto the M active site, which is formed by substituting In1 at the same position, while carbon dioxide is adsorbed onto the oxygen vacancy (Ov), as shown in Fig. 1(a). The adsorption of methane on the M/In2O3 surfaces is relatively weak, with adsorption energies ranging from -0.20 to -0.24 eV, indicating typical physical adsorption. Specifically, the Cu-C bond on the Cu/In2O3 surface has a length of 3.21 Å, which is the configuration for the activation of the C-H bond. In the final state, the methyl and H protons are adsorbed on the surface, forming Cu-CH3 species and surface Brønsted acids. At this point, the length of the Cu-C bond changes to 1.98 Å. The changes in bond lengths for the dehydrogenation process on other surfaces (M/In2O3) are shown in Tables S3 and S4. The heterolytic cleavage dissociation of CH4 on the Cu1-O3 species can be confirmed through Bader charge analysis. In this analysis, CH3* acquires +0.1|e| charge at the Cu site, while H* acquires -0.55|e| charge at the O site. Bader charge analysis for other surfaces is presented in Tables S1 and S2. During CH4 dissociation, the Cu-C bond measures 2.59 Å on the transition state, and the energy barrier required to break the C-H bond is 0.99 eV. Additionally, the heat of the reaction is 0.71 eV, indicating that the dissociation of CH4 is an endothermic process. As a control, we also investigated the methane dehydrogenation process on the In2O3 (111) surface containing only oxygen vacancies. The potential energy diagrams for the dehydrogenation processes on M/In2O3 and In2O3 surfaces are shown in Fig. 2(a). The activation energy values are as follows: Cu/In2O3 (0.99 eV) < Ag/In2O3 (1.08 eV) < Zn/In2O3 (1.17 eV) < Cd/In2O3 (1.38 eV) < In2O3 (1.72 eV). We observed that the Bader charge obtained for the dissociated methyl group is proportional to the activating energy on the surfaces of M/In2O3. Fig. 2(d) displays the top view of the dehydrogenation intermediates on the surface of M/In2O3 and In2O3 surfaces. The relative energy and structures involved in the dehydrogenation process are illustrated in Figs. S4 and S5. The bottom line is this, the M active site on the M/In2O3 surface enhances the catalytic performance of methane dehydrogenation compared to the In active site on the In2O3 surface at the identical location. While the aforementioned studies have confirmed the exceptional catalytic performance of M active sites in methane dehydrogenation, we cannot discount the possibility that In sites on the M/In2O3 surface also exhibit strong catalytic activity. Therefore, we will classify the active sites into two categories, In2 and In3, based on their proximity to the oxygen vacancies. Fig. 2(b) and (c) display the activation energies of the methane dehydrogenation process at In2 and In3, respectively. Except for the methane dehydrogenation activation energy at the In2 active site on the Cd/In2O3 surface, which is slightly smaller than the Cd active site, the activation energies at all other sites are larger than the M active site. However, since the In2 active site is far away from the oxygen vacancy, which is unfavorable for the subsequent C-C coupling radical reaction, we can neglect the minor enhancement of catalytic performance at In2 on the Cd/In2O3 surface. Fig. 2(e) and (f) show the transition states for methane dehydrogenation at In2 and In3, respectively. Ultimately, we can conclude that the transition metal M position represents the most favorable active site for methane dehydrogenation. The incorporation of transition metal M activates the In active sites near the oxygen vacancy, resulting in a lower activation energy barrier for methane dissociation. The collaborative interaction between the In active sites and the M active site greatly enhances the formation of acetic acid. The structures and relative energies of methane dehydrogenation at In2 and In3 are shown in Figs. S4, S6, and S7. It is worth noting that the coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species enables better activation of methane as depicted in Fig. 3(a). The coordination environment of transition metal M in the other catalysts is shown in Fig. S8. Previously, researchers have reported that the coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species has been identified as the active center for methanol production through carbon dioxide hydrogenation, exhibiting 100 % selectivity towards methanol [60]. This structure also serves as the active site for carbon monoxide oxidation, displaying a carbon monoxide consumption rate that is 20 times higher compared to other Cu-based catalysts [61]. During the reaction, the coordination number of Cu-O slightly decreased to 2 due to the bonding of the CH3* to Cu, accompanied by a slight decrease in valence. The Cu-Osurface bond lengths remained relatively unchanged. whereas the Cu-Oinner bond lengths slightly increased under the reaction conditions (from 2.16 to 2.33 Å), indicating the activation of Cu1-O3 sites under the reaction conditions. The changes in Cu-O bond lengths before and after the reaction are shown in Table S6. To further understand the interactions between the methyl species and the Cu1-O3 structure, we analyzed the partial density of states (PDOS) and crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) of Cu and C and plotted the results in Fig. 3(b). Based on previous reports [30,62], it is evident that there is a strong overlap between the s and p orbitals of C and the s state of Cu. This significant overlap strongly implies the formation of a stable Cu-C bond, resulting in the stabilization of the adsorbed methyl group on the copper surface. A large antibonding state is present near the Fermi energy level of COHP-Cu/In2O3. In addition, antibonding orbital populations are appearing at 4.5, 5.7, 8.1, and -2.2, suggesting unstable adsorption of CH3 species. To quantitatively compare the interaction strength, the integrated COHP (ICOHP) was calculated. yielding an ICOHP of -2.04 eV (Cu/In2O3). As illustrated in Fig. S9, the adsorption of CH3 species on Cu1-O3 is less stable compared to M/In2O3 (ICOHP(Zn/In2O3)=-2.73, ICOHP(Ag/In2O3)=-2.31, ICOHP(Cd/In2O3)=-2.04). The coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species is expected to exhibit superior performance than other surfaces in the C-C coupling process. The formation of acetic acid Fig. 4 illustrates the energy barrier diagrams for the formation of acetic acid by four single-atom catalysts. The yellow and green lines represent the reaction pathways for Zn/In2O3 and Cd/In2O3, respectively, in forming acetic acid. The orange and blue lines correspond to the reaction pathways for Cu/In2O3 and Ag/In2O3, respectively, in forming acetic acid. The reaction energies and activation energies for C-C coupling on the surface of M/In2O3 (M=Cu, Zn, Ag, Cd) are (-2.04 eV, 1.59 eV), (-1.77 eV, 2.85 eV), (-1.97 eV, 1.96 eV), and (-001.76 eV, 3.33 eV), respectively. In the initial state, the carbon dioxide bond angle is slightly activated to 177.12° (as shown in Table S4). The bond angle of the transition state decreases to 173.24°, and then becomes 121.86° in the final state. During this process, CO2* migrates to the vicinity of the Cu-C bond, and the C atom of CO2* forms a bond with the C atom of CH3*, leading to the extension of the Cu-C bond from 1.98 to 4.13 Å. The procession mentioned above is considered to be the rate-determining step of the reaction, and Cu/In2O3 demonstrates exceptional catalytic performance. In the previous section, we conducted COHP analysis on the M-C bond on the M/In2O3 (111) surface. The unique structural characteristics of the Cu1-O3 result in the weakest bond strength between the Cu atom and the C atom in CH3*, making it prone to breakage, thereby promoting the occurrence of C-C coupling. To further explain the differential of C-C coupling on the M/In2O3 (111) surface, we analyzed the electronic structure features of the transition states. Bader charge analysis (refer to Table S8) revealed that Cu/In2O3 (111) transfers 0.48|e| to the transition state (H3C-COO)*, while the remaining three catalysts transfer 0.12|e|, 0.15|e|, and 0.03|e| to (H3C-COO)*. We found that the Cu/In2O3 surface can transfer more electrons to (H3C-COO)* due to its Cu1-O3 species, indicating a strong interaction between them. It is observed from the charge density difference map in Table S7 of the Cu/In2O3 that the (H3C-COO)* also exhibits a high charge accumulation, indicating the transition state is very stable. These property aligns with the results of the activation energy calculations. After the formation of CH3COO* species, the H protons migrate to the CH3COO*, resulting in the formation of acetic acid. The process is a heat-absorbing reaction [23]. Depending on the location of the H proton migration, we have analyzed two styles on the Cu/In2O3 surface, which we have named path A and path B. In path A, one oxygen atom of CH3COOH* adsorbs onto the surface of Cu, and the "O-C-O-H" forms a "n"-type structure as depicted in Fig. 5(b), A3 model. In path B, one oxygen of CH3COOH* adsorbs on the surface of In, and the "H-O-C-O" forms a "И"-type structure as shown in Fig. 5(b), B3 model. The potential energy calculations for these two different paths are presented in Fig. 5(a), and it can be observed that the reaction energies and activation energies for path A and path B are (1.17 eV, 1.15 eV) and (1.05 eV, 1.50 eV), respectively. CH3COOH* with the "n"-type bonding configuration exhibits a significant kinetic advantage. Moreover, since the free acetic acid molecule also possesses a "n"-type structure, path A requires one less step of structural adjustment compared to path B, highlighting the advantages of path A in the formation of acetic acid. As illustrated in Fig. 4, the reaction energies and activation energies for the formation of acetic acid on the M/In2O3 (M=Zn, Ag, Cd) surface are as follows: (0.99 eV, 1.01 eV), (1.29 eV, 1.46 eV), (0.65 eV, 0.68 eV), respectively. It is worth highlighting that the hydrogenation of CH3COO species on the Cd/In2O3 surface demonstrates significant advantages in both kinetics and thermodynamics. This is primarily because of the Cd/In2O3 surface's high relative energy and poor stability of the CH3COO species. The complete structural details and associated energy profiles during the hydrogenation process of CH3COO species are depicted in Fig. S10. It is lower than the previously reported energy barriers for the reaction, such as [24] Ag1-FLP (1.12 eV), [17] Pd/ZrO2 (1.28 eV), and [18] ZrO2–2SO2 (1.42 eV). In conclusion, the Cu/In2O3 catalyst has been identified as the optimal catalyst for the production of acetic acid from carbon dioxide and methane. The formation of formic acid and methyl formate In this study, we have also investigated the formation process of formic acid and methyl formate on the Cu/In 2 O 3 surface. Fig. 6(a) shows the potential energy diagram for the formation of formic acid and methyl formate. Upon adsorption of CH4 and CO2 on the surface, the H proton from methane migrates to the C atom of carbon dioxide, resulting in the formation of the HCOO* species (Fig. 6(b) and (c)). Throughout this process, the angle of carbon dioxide gradually decreases from 176.21° to 120.78°. The activation energy barrier and reaction energy for this elementary reaction are measured to be 2.10 eV and 0.28 eV, respectively. We observed that breaking the C=O double bond (CO2) and forming the C-H single bond (HCOO*) simultaneously is exceedingly challenging. The aforementioned step is a shared process in the formation of formic acid and methyl formate, differing primarily in the bonding between the oxygen in HCOO* and either a hydrogen or a carbon in the methyl group. Fig. 6(b) and (c) illustrate the transitional states and intermediates involved in the formation of formic acid and methyl formate, respectively. The activation energies and reaction energies for the establishment of the O-H and O-C bonds are (1.39 eV, 0.36 eV) and (1.31 eV, 0.06 eV) correspondingly. This analysis suggests that methyl formate is more prone to form on the surface. In addition, the O-C coupling process on the Cu/In2O3 surface demonstrates outstanding performance in comparison to the H proton migration process. When comparing the C-C coupling (1.59 eV) on the Cu/In 2 O 3 surface to the C-H (2.10 eV) coupling, we observed that it is relatively easier to generate acetic acid on the Cu/In2O3 surface. The microkinetic model for the formation of CH3COOH and HCOOCH3 To provide a more intuitive observation of the differences in the forming of acetic acid and methyl formate on the Cu/In2O3 surface, we conducted a microkinetic modeling based on DFT calculations. The appendix describes the computational method used to solve the microkinetic equations, which includes all the elementary steps involved in the forming of acetic acid and methyl formate on the Cu/In2O3 surface. For the microkinetic simulation of elementary steps, we set the vacancy coverage to 1 and the methane coverage to 0 ML [63]. The selected temperature for the simulation was within the typical experimental conditions [16,17] (T = 500–900 K, P = 1 bar, CH4:CO2=1:1). In Fig. 7(a), the dominant coverage is of CH3 species, primarily due to methane dehydrogenation, which is the first step after surface adsorption. This is followed by a high energy barrier for C-O (2.10 eV) and C-C (1.59 eV) coupling. As the temperature increases, the coverage of CH3 species gradually decreases, while the average coverage of HCOO and CH3COO species increases. This indicates that higher temperatures favor C-C and C-O coupling reactions. We also calculated the turnover frequencies (TOF) for the forming of acetic acid and methyl formate, which have been illustrated in Fig. 7(b). Within the range of T = 500–900 K, the TOF for acetic acid-forming on the Cu/In2O3 surface ranges between 2E-6 and 2E-5 site−1s−1, while the TOF for methyl formate formation ranges between 2E-9 and 2E-8 site−1s−1. At the same temperature, The TOF for acetic acid formation on the Cu/In2O3 surface is 3-4 orders of magnitude higher than that for methyl formate formation, indicating a higher advantage for acetic acid formation on the Cu/In2O3 surface. Conclusions In this paper, we studied the catalytic conversion of methane and carbon dioxide to acetic acid by doping transition metal M on the oxygen-deficient In2O3 (111) surface. We observed that by doping transition metal M, the catalytic performance of its surface In active sites for methane dehydrogenation is enhanced, and the activation energy of the M active sites for methane dehydrogenation is minimized. Hence, the coordination bond between the transition metal M and oxygen atoms serves as the optimal active site for methane activation and dehydrogenation, while the nearby oxygen vacancies act as active sites for carbon dioxide adsorption and activation. This work compared the formation processes of acetic acid on four different M/In2O3 (M=Cu, Zn, Ag, Cd) surfaces. We found that Cu/In2O3 exhibited the best catalytic performance. Additionally, we carried out Density of States and Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population calculations for Cu-CH3*, and discovered that Cu/In2O3, with its coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species, had significant advantages in methane dehydrogenation and C-C coupling. The hydrogenation of acetate through the “H-O-C-O” bonding in an “n” configuration is more favorable for the formation of acetic acid. Finally, based on DFT calculations and microkinetic analysis, it is shown that the formation of acetic acid is more favorable on the Cu/In2O3 surface compared to methyl formate. This work aims to advance the experimental preparation of acetic acid from methane and carbon dioxide through this study, while also offering guidance for the development of catalysts based on copper. coredata.dc:description: The co-conversion of CH4 and CO2 has emerged as a challenging issue in C1 chemistry. Converting these gases into a high-value product like acetic acid is an attractive solution. In this study, we employed density-functional theory calculations to design dual-active single-atom catalysts M/In2O3 (M=Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd), which incorporated oxygen vacancies. These catalysts were created by introducing metal M into the surface of In2O3 (111) through doping. Cu/In2O3, Zn/In2O3, Ag/In2O3, and Cd/In2O3 were selected based on the stability of forming single-atom catalysts. Our findings indicated that the formation of the M/In2O3 surface activates the In surface activity and significantly lowers the activation energy for methane dehydrogenation. Among them, the Cu1-O3 species on the Cu/In2O3 surface demonstrates a lower activation energy for methane dehydrogenation and C-C coupling reactions. The "H-O-C-O" hydrogenation of CH3COO* species bonded with the "n"-type structure is more realistic. Microkinetic analysis indicated that the average turnover frequency for the forming of acetic acid on the Cu/In2O3 surface is three orders of magnitude greater than that of methyl formate. This research provides theoretical support for the development of copper single-atom catalysts for the efficient conversion of CO2 and CH4 into acetic acid.
coredata.dc:title: The role of coordination-unsaturated Cu1-O3 species in the single-atom catalyst Cu/In2O3 for the preparation of acetic acid from methane and carbon dioxide
